questions.text: A 32-Year-old woman with a diagnosis of dysfunctional uterine bleeding failed to respond to medical therapy. So you are planning for endometrial ablation. All of the following are contraindications for hysteroscopic endometrial ablation except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uterine size < 12 weeks Uterine size > 12 weeks is a contraindication of hysteroscopic endometrial ablation not < 12 weeks .

Highyeild:

After hysteroscopic ablation uterine cavity anatomy is distorted by uterine wall agglutination and intracavitary synechiae, in the long term leading to: 1) Hematometra 2) Inadequate hysteroscopic biopsy for future evaluation. Other contraindications of hysteroscopic endometrial ablation are: Uterine fibroid > 4 cm Scarred uterus (previous surgery) Young women desirous of pregnancy Adenomyosis Acute pelvic infection Uterine cancer or preinvasive cancer, atypical hyperplasia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C, and D are true.

Extraedge:

PALM-COEIN classification is used to describe the etiology of AUB . Up to 15% of patients with abnormal vaginal bleeding (especially in the adolescent age group) have coagulation disorders. The most common cause of AUB in adolescent girls and perimenopausal women is anovulation.

questions.text: An 18-Year-old girl visited gynecology OPD for complaints of spotting a few days before menstruation for 6 months. You suspect irregular ripening of the endometrium. All of the following are true about irregular ripening except?

questions.explanation:

Also known as Halban disease Halban disease is irregular shedding of the endometrium, not irregular ripening . Halban disease is due to persistent corpus luteum. Menstruation comes on time, prolonged but not heavy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Irregular ripening is due to deficient corpus luteal function. Option: C. Irregular ripening is an Ovulatory bleeding, that occurs before the actual menstruation in the form of spotting or brownish discharge. Option: D. Progesterone should be given during the late luteal phase for the treatment of irregular ripening.

questions.text: A 38-Year-old woman presented to gynecology OPD with complaints of excessive menstrual bleeding associated with abdominal pain and also intermenstrual bleeding for a year. The ultrasound of the patient is given below. All of the following are true regarding the diagnosis except?

questions.correct_answer: A. The endometrial polyp is made up of only stroma but not glands
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The endometrial polyp is made up of only stroma but not glands The endometrial polyp is composed of endometrial glands and stroma covered with a single layer of columnar epithelium.

Highyeild:

Endometrial polyps are seen in peri and postmenopausal women and cause irregular/ intermenstrual bleeding. Endometrial polyps are likely to negatively impact fertility and impair implantation. The treatment is hysteroscopic polypectomy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Polyp may be malignant from initial or benign polyp may become malignant. In a malignant polyp, the entire polyp shows malignancy, including its base whereas secondary malignancy is seen at the apex of the polyp. Option C. Management of endometrial polyp includes scraping by dilatation and curettage. Hysteroscopic removal of multiple polyps may be desirable to ensure their complete removal. Option D. A fibroid polyp, is a submucous fibroid developing a pedicle and protruding into the uterine cavity or projecting through with a long pedicle.

Extraedge:

On USG Doppler feeder vessel sign is seen.

This causes painless bleeding , not pain.

Side effects of tranexamic acid are nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, visual disturbances, and intracranial thrombosis.

questions.text: You are in consultation with a 14-Year-old female whose menstrual cycle duration is 18 days. What will you term this as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Polymenorrhea

Highyeild:

Amenorrhoea is a term used if the time period between two menstrual cycles is more than 90 days. Oligomenorrhoea denotes infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding usually occurring at intervals of more than 38 days. Polymenorrhoea denotes frequent episodes of menstruation, usually occurring at intervals of 24 days or less. Menometorrhagia means excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals.

questions.text: A 28-Year-old nulligravid patient complains of bleeding between her periods and increasingly heavy menses. Over the past 9 months, a trial of oral contraceptives and antiprostaglandins has failed to decrease the abnormal, heavy bleeding. Which of the following options is most appropriate at this time?

options.label: D
options.text: Start the patient on GnRH agonist

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perform hysteroscopy In patients with abnormal bleeding who are not responding to standard therapy, a hysteroscopy should be performed.

Highyeild:

Hysteroscopy can rule out endometrial polyps or small fibroids, which, if present, can be resected. In patients with heavy abnormal bleeding who no longer desire fertility, endometrial ablation may be performed.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: If a patient has completed childbearing and is having significant abnormal bleeding, a hysteroscopy, rather than a hysterectomy, would still be the procedure of choice to rule out easily treatable diseases. Option B: Would be indicated in a woman who has completed her family and doesn't desire pregnancy.

questions.text: A 14-Year-old has been bleeding heavily for the past 2 weeks and now feels a bit dizzy and light-headed. Menarche attained about 6 months ago, and since that time her periods have been irregular and very heavy. She appears very pale and fatigued. Her blood pressure and pulse are 110/60mm Hg and 70 beats per minute, respectively. When you stand her up, her blood pressure remains stable, but her pulse increases to 100. She reports that she has never been sexually active. On physical examinations, her abdomen is benign. As she is unmarried per vaginal examination is not performed. She is 5 ft 4 inch tall and weight is 75kgs. Which of the following blood tests is not indicated in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Estradiol level The case presented is a typical representation of a patient with dysfunctional uterine bleeding attributed to anovulation.

Highyeild:

The onset of menarche in young women is typically followed by approximately 5 years of irregular cycles that result from anovulation secondary to the immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. Measuring an estradiol level would serve no purpose in the workup of this patient. Uterine cancer, cervical polyps, or cervical pathology would be rare in a girl of this age. These other causes of abnormal bleeding would be more common in older women.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B, and C are false. Options A, B, and C : Pregnancy should always be considered as a possible cause in all women of reproductive age. Appropriate lab tests to order in the emergency room would be a BHCG (to rule out pregnancy), a bleeding time (20% of adolescents with dysfunctional uterine bleeding have a coagulation defect), and blood type and screen (since she is orthostatic she may require a blood transfusion).

questions.text: A 48-Year-old woman attends the gynecology clinic complaining of heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) and occasional intermenstrual bleeding. Her hemoglobin level is 11.2 g/l. An ultrasound scan demonstrated no obvious abnormality. What other investigation is required?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endometrial biopsy If appropriate, a biopsy should be taken to exclude endometrial cancer or atypical hyperplasia . Indications for a biopsy include, for example, persistent intermenstrual bleeding, and, in women aged 45 and over, treatment failure or ineffective treatment.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A and C . Have no role in this patient. Option D: Serum FSH levels are done in other conditions like when premature ovarian failure is suspected, but not for this patient.

questions.text: A 46-Year-old female P2L2 presents with a history of increasing menses since 7 months. She also complains of irregular bleeding associated with severe abdominal pain. Her symptoms are associated with weakness and anorexia. She is hypertensive and diabetic with tuberculosis and is on medication. On examination, her vitals are Pulse- 80 bpm, BP- 128/70 mmHg, and temperature 99.5F. Per vaginal examination shows no findings. False statement about this condition is:

options.label: A
options.text: The segmented nodular appearance of tubes is seen

options.label: B
options.text: HSG is contraindicated in diagnosed cases

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Proximal tube obstruction Proximal tube obstruction is false as distal tube obstruction is seen. Options A, B, and C are true.

Highyeild:

The clinical case is of genital tuberculosis . It can present with symptoms of menorrhagia with dysmenorrhea or infertility. In most cases, it may be asymptomatic. HSG is contraindicated in proven cases as it may cause reactivation of the lesions. HSG when done as a routine workup for infertility shows the following features: Vascular or lymphatic extravasation of dye. Rigid (lead-pipe) tubes with nodulations at places. Tobacco pouch appearance with the blocked fimbrial end. The beaded appearance of the tube with variable filling density. Distal tube obstruction. Coiling of the tubes or calcified shadow at places. Bilateral cornual block. Tubal diverticula and/or fluffiness of tubal outline. Uterine cavity-irregular outline, honeycomb appearance, or presence of uterine synechiae.
